atypic

Effects

class Effect(frame, opacity=255, mask=None)[source]

Bases: object

Base class for image/video effects.

Parameters:

  • frame (numpy.ndarray) – The video frame to apply the effect on.

  • opacity (int) – Opacity of the effect (0-255). 255 is fully visible, 0 is invisible.

  • mask (numpy.ndarray, optional) – A mask (0-255) defining the region and strength to apply the effect. If None, the effect applies to the entire frame.

blend()[source]

Blend the original frame and the effected frame using mask and opacity.

Returns:

The blended frame.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

class ColorChannelSplit(frame, split_distance=0.1, which='row', order='bgr', **kwargs)[source]

Bases: Effect

Apply a color channel split effect to an image frame.

This effect shifts each color channel (B, G, R) by a specified distance.

Initialize the effect with a frame, split distance, direction, and channel order.

Parameters:

  • frame (numpy.ndarray) – The video frame to apply the effect on.

  • split_distance (int | float) – Distance to shift each color channel. If float, it is interpreted as a proportion of the frame size.

  • which (str) – Direction of the split, either ‘row’ or ‘col’.

  • order (str) – Order of color channels to apply the effect on (‘bgr’, ‘rgb’, etc.).

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments for the Effect base class.

apply()[source]

Apply the color channel split effect to the frame.

class ColorPaletteReduction(frame, num_colors=4, **kwargs)[source]

Bases: Effect

Apply a color palette reduction effect to an image frame.

This effect reduces the number of colors in the frame to a specified number.

Initialize the effect with a frame and number of colors.

Parameters:

  • frame (numpy.ndarray) – The video frame to apply the effect on.

  • num_colors (int) – Number of colors to reduce the frame to.

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments for the Effect base class.

apply()[source]

Apply the color palette reduction effect to the frame.

This method quantizes each color channel to the specified number of colors.

class ColorValue(frame, shift_values: tuple[int, int, int] | tuple[float, float, float] = (0.2, 0.2, 0.2), **kwargs)[source]

Bases: Effect

Apply a color value shift effect to an image frame.

This effect shifts the color values of the frame by a specified amount.

Initialize the effect with a frame and shift value.

Parameters:

  • frame (numpy.ndarray) – The video frame to apply the effect on.

  • shift_value (tuple[float, float, float]) – Amount to multiply the color values, for each channel (B, G, R).

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments for the Effect base class.

apply()[source]

Apply the color shift effect to the frame.

class Corruption(frame, corruption_type='random', bitsize=0.01, **kwargs)[source]

Bases: Effect

Apply a corruption effect to an image frame.

This effect randomly corrupts blocks of pixels in the frame.

Initialize the effect with a frame, corruption type, and bitsize.

Parameters:

  • frame (numpy.ndarray) – The video frame to apply the effect on.

  • corruption_type (str) – Type of corruption to apply (e.g., ‘random’).

  • bitsize (int | float) – Size of the corruption block. If float, it is interpreted as a proportion of the frame size.

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments for the Effect base class.

apply()[source]

Apply the corruption effect to the frame.

class RollPixels(frame, which='row', shift_length=0.1, **kwargs)[source]

Bases: Effect

Apply a pixel roll effect to an image frame.

Initialize the effect with a frame, direction, and shift length.

Parameters:

  • frame (numpy.ndarray) – The video frame to apply the effect on. which (str): Direction of the roll, either ‘row’ or ‘col’.

  • shift_length (int | float) – Length of the pixel shift. If float, it is interpreted as a proportion of the frame size.

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments for the Effect base class.

apply()[source]

Apply the pixel roll effect to the frame.

class RollPixelsRandom(frame, which='row', group_size=0.2, shift_range=(0.1, 0.1), **kwargs)[source]

Bases: RollPixels

Apply a random pixel roll effect to an image frame.

This effect randomly shifts blocks of pixels in either rows or columns.

Initialize the effect with a frame, direction, group size, and shift range.

Parameters:

  • frame (numpy.ndarray) – The video frame to apply the effect on.

  • which (str) – Direction of the roll, either ‘row’ or ‘col’.

  • group_size (int | float) – Size of the pixel block to shift. If float, it is interpreted as a proportion of the frame size.

  • shift_range (tuple[int | float, int | float]) – Range of random shifts. If floats, they are interpreted as proportions of the frame size.

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments for the Effect base class.

apply()[source]

Apply the random pixel roll effect to the frame.

class Sort(frame, which='row', sort_by='value', reverse=False, **kwargs)[source]

Bases: Effect

Apply a sorting effect to an image frame.

This effect sorts pixels in a specified direction (row or column) based on their color values.

Initialize the effect with a frame, direction, sorting criteria, and reverse flag.

Parameters:

  • frame (numpy.ndarray) – The video frame to apply the effect on. which (str): Direction of the sort, either ‘row’ or ‘col’.

  • sort_by (str) – Criteria to sort by (‘value’, ‘r’, ‘g’, ‘b’). If ‘value’, sorts by average color value; if ‘r’, ‘g’, or ‘b’, sorts by that channel.

  • reverse (bool) – If True, reverses the sort order.

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments for the Effect base class.

apply()[source]

Apply the sorting effect to the frame.

Mask

class Masker(frame, behavior='add')[source]

Bases: object

A class to create and manage masks for video frames.

It allows for the creation of various shapes and patterns as masks, which can be applied to video frames. The masks can be combined using different behaviors such as ‘or’, ‘and’, ‘xor’, ‘nand’, and ‘nor’.

Parameters:

  • frame (np.ndarray) – The video frame to apply masks to.

  • behavior (str, optional) – The default behavior for combining masks (‘or’, ‘and’, ‘xor’, ‘nand’, ‘nor’).

create_band(orientation='horizontal', start=0, end=None, behavior=None, opacity=255)[source]

Create a horizontal or vertical band mask.

Parameters:

  • orientation (str) – ‘horizontal’ or ‘vertical’

  • start (int | float) – Starting index of the band

  • end (int | float, optional) – Ending index of the band (defaults to frame edge)

  • behavior (str, optional) – Masker combination behavior

Returns:

A Masker instance with the band mask.

Return type:

Masker

create_checkerboard(block_size=10, behavior=None, opacity=255)[source]

Create a checkerboard pattern mask.

Parameters:

  • block_size (int | float) – Size of each square block

  • behavior (str, optional) – Masker combination behavior

Returns:

A Masker instance with the checkerboard mask.

Return type:

Masker

create_circle(center, radius, behavior=None, opacity=255)[source]

Create a circular mask.

Parameters:

  • center (tuple[int, int] | tuple[float, float]) – (x, y) coordinates of the circle center

  • radius (int | float) – Radius of the circle

  • behavior (str, optional) – Masker combination behavior

Returns:

A Masker instance with the circular mask.

Return type:

Masker

create_ellipse(center, axes, angle=0, behavior=None, opacity=255)[source]

Create an elliptical mask.

Parameters:

  • center (tuple[int, int] | tuple[float, float]) – (x, y) coordinates of the ellipse center

  • axes (tuple[int, int] | tuple[float, float]) – (major_axis_length, minor_axis_length)

  • angle (float, optional) – Rotation angle of the ellipse in degrees

  • behavior (str, optional) – Masker combination behavior

Returns:

A Masker instance with the elliptical mask.

Return type:

Masker

  • behavior (str, optional) – Masker combination behavior

A Masker instance with the polygon mask.

Create a regular polygon mask.

Parameters:

  • radius (int | float) – Radius of the circumscribed circle

  • sides (int) – Number of sides of the polygon

  • behavior (str, optional) – Masker combination behavior

Returns:

A Masker instance with the regular polygon mask.

Masker

  • points (int) – Number of points in the star

  • behavior (str, optional) – Masker combination behavior

rotate(angle)[source]

Rotate the instance mask element by a specified angle.

Parameters:

angle (float) – The angle in degrees to rotate the mask.

mirror(axis='vertical')[source]

Mirror a given mask element in the specified direction.

Parameters:

  • mask_element (Masker) – The Masker instance containing the mask to be mirrored.

  • axis (str) – ‘horizontal’ or ‘vertical’

add(*mask_elements, behavior=None)[source]

Combine multiple mask elements into a single mask and add them to current Masker instance.

Parameters:

  • *mask_elements (Masker) – The Masker instances to combine.

  • behavior (str, optional) – Masker combination behavior

Returns:

A new Masker instance containing the combined mask.

Return type:

Masker
